body:
Changing it from `char` to `String` would be a breaking change. On the other hand,  `@CsvSource` is still experimental although widely used.

Tentatively slated for 5.6 M1 for _team discussion_.

Yes, I experimented with using `@CompileStatic`, but unfortunately then I lose access to other Groovy features that I was using.

So far, I like being able to use the `@CsvSource` and see the inputs and expected outputs right above the test.

Perhaps something Groovy 3.x will support w/o resorting to `String`?

Because only to support `","` -- a single character sequence -- I'd hesitate to change the API of `@CsvSource`.

Perhaps rather than changing the API, a new one could be created.  Since the univocity parser allows string delimiters with more than one character, I thought it might be a nice enhancement which not only supports groovy's lack of a character literal, but also allows for a wider set of delimiters to be used.

> Perhaps rather than changing the API, a new one could be created. Since the univocity parser allows string delimiters with more than one character, I thought it might be a nice enhancement which not only supports groovy's lack of a character literal, but also allows for a wider set of delimiters to be used.

I suppose we could introduce something like `delimiterString`. It's not the most elegant and would require a more complicated lookup algorithm (that rejects configuration of both attributes), but it's possible.

**Team Decision:** Let's add `delimiterString`, check that the user does not declare both delimiter attributes, set the default values in the annotation to `'\0'` and `""`, respectively, and default to `,` when no delimiter is set.
...and default to ',' (comma character) when no delimiter is set?

> ...and default to ',' (comma character) when no delimiter is set?

Yes, exactly. That was discussed during the call but didn't make it into the "Team Decision".
I'd like to take a look at that if it's ok with you :)

issue.title: Add support for String delimiters in @CsvSource and @CsvFileSource

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Solves #1958 by adding a `delimiterString` attribute to the `@CsvSource` annotation.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
- [x] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass

rename.from: Add support for String delimiters in @CsvSource

body:
> I'd like to take a look at that if it's ok with you :)

Well, it was assigned to me, but I'm totally happy that you've submitted a PR to address this.  

Cheers,

Sam

> Well, it was assigned to me, but I'm totally happy that you've submitted a PR to address this. 

Yes I saw that afterwards, sorry!
